At London printed by George eld, and are to be sold at his house in Fleet-lane at the sign of the printers-press. 1608.

div.head: A trick to catch the old one.

sp.speaker: Witt-good.
sp.p: All's gone! still thou'rt a gentleman, that's all; but a poor one, that's nothing: what milk brings thy meadows forth now? where are thy goodly uplands and thy down-lands, all sunk into that little pit lechery? why should a gallant pay but two shillings for his ordinary that nourishes him, and twenty times two for his brothel that consumes him? but where's Long-acre? in my uncle's conscience, which is 3. years voyage about; he that sets out upon his conscience, ne'er finds the way home again, he is either swallowed in the quicksands of law-quillets, or splits upon the piles of a praemunire; yet these old fox-brained — and ox-browed uncles, have still defences for their avarice, and apologies for their practises, and will thus greet our follies.

lg.l: He that doth his youth expose,
Let him that is his nearest kin,

sp.p: And that's his uncle, 'tis a principle in usury; I dare not visit the city, there I should be too soon visited, by that horrible plague my debts, and by that means I lose a virgin's love, her portion and her virtues, well, how should a man live now, that has no living; hum? why are there not a million of men in the world, that only sojourn upon their brain, and make their wits their mercers; and am I but one amongst that million and cannot thrive upon't; any trick out of the compass of law now, would come happily to me.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: My love.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: My loathing; hast thou been the secret consumption of my purse? and now com'st to undo my last means, my wits? wilt leave no virtue in me and yet thou ne'er the better? hence courtesan, round webbed tarantula.
That driest the roses in the cheeks of youth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I have been true unto your pleasure, and all your lands thrice racked, was never worth the jewel which I prodigally gave you, my virginity;
Lands mortgaged may return and more esteemed,
But honesty once pawned, is never redeemed.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: For give I do thee wrong,
To make thee sin, and then to chid thee fort.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I know I am your loathing now, farewell.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Stay best invention, — stay.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I that have been the secret consumption of your purse shall I stay now to undo your last means, your wits? hence courtesan away.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I prithee, make me not mad at my own weapon, stay, (A thing few women can do I know that, and therefore they had need wear stays;) be not contrary, dost love me?
Fate has so cast it that all my means I must derive from thee.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: From me! be happy then,
What lies within the power of my performance,
Shall be commanded of thee.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Spoken like an honest drab i'faith, it may prove something what trick is not an embryon at first, until a perfect shape come over it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Come I must help you whereabouts left you,
I'll proceed.
Though you beget, 'tis I must help to breed,
Speak what is't, I'd fain conceive it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: So, so, so, thou shall presently take the name and form upon thee of a rich country widow four hundred a year valiant, in woods, in bullocks, in barns and in rye-stacks, we'll to London , and to my covetous uncle.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I begin to applaud thee, our states being both desperate, they are soon resolute, but how for horses?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Mass that's true, the jest will be of some continuance, let me see, horses now, a bott's on 'em; stay, I have acquaintance with a mad host, never yet bawd to thee, I have rinsed the whoresons gums in mull-sack many a time and often, put but a good tale into his ear now, so it come off cleanly, and there's horse and man for us I dare warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Arm your wits then speedily, there shall want nothing in me, either in behaviour, discourse or fashion, that shall discredit your entended purpose.
I will so artfully disguise my wants,
And set so good a courage on my state,
That I will be believed.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why then all's furnished; I shall go nigh to catch that old fox mine uncle, though he make but some amends for my undoing, yet there's some comfort in't — he cannot otherwise choose (Though it be but in hope to cozen me again) but supply any hasty want that I bring to town with me, the device well and cunningly carried, the name of a rich widow, and four hundred a year in good earth, will so conjure up a kind of usurer's love in him to me, that he will not only desire my presence, which at first shall scarce be granted him, I'll keep off a purpose, but I shall find him so officious to deserve, so ready to supply, I know the state of an old man's affection so well, if his nephew be poor indeed, why he lets God alone with him, but if he be once rich, than he'll be the first man that helps him.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: 'Tis right the world, for in these days an old man's love to his kindred, is like his kindness to his wife, 'tis always done before he comes at it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
I owe thee for that jest, be gone, here's all my wealth; prepare thyself, away? I'll to mine host withal possible haste, and with the best art, and most profitable form, pour the sweet
circumstance into his ear, which shall have the gift to turn all the wax to honey; how no; o the right worshipful seniors of our country —
Who's that;
O the common rioter, take no note of him.

sp.speaker: Witg.
sp.p: You will not see me now, the comfort is ere it be long you will scarce see yourselves.
I wonder how he breathes, has consumed all upon that courtesan?
We have heard so much.

sp.l: You have heard all truth, his uncle and my brother, have been these three years mortal adversaries. Two old tough spirits, they seldom meet but fight, or quarrel when 'tis calmest;
I think their anger be the very fire
That keeps their age alive:

sp.p: What was the quarrel sir?

Faith about a purchase, fetching over a young heir; master Hoord my brother having wasted much time in beating the bargain, what did me old lucre ▪ but as his conscience moved him, knowing the poor gentleman , stepped in between 'em and cozened him himself.
And was this all sir:

This was e'en it sir, yet for all this I know no reason but the match might go forward betwixt his wife's son and my niece, what though there be a dissension between the two old men, I see no reason it should put a difference between the two younger, 'tis as natural for old folks to fall out, as for young to fall in? A scholar comes a-wooing to my niece, well, he's wise, but he's poor, her son comes a-wooing to my niece, well, he's a fool, but he's rich —
I marry sir?
Pray now is not a rich fool better than a poor philosopher.
One would think so i'faith?

She now remains at London with my brother her second
uncle, to learn fashions, practise music, the voice between her lips, and the viol between her legs, she'll be fit for a consort very speedily, a thousand good pound is her portion, if she marry, we'll ride up and be merry, —
A match, if it be a match?

div.stage: Enter at one door, Witt-good, at the other host.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Mine host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Young master Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit,
sp.p: I have been laying all the town for thee.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why what's the news Bully-hadland?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What geldings are in the house of thine own? answer me to that first.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why man, why?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Mark me what I say, I'll tell thee such a tale in thine ear, that thou shalt trust me spite of thy teeth, furnish me with some money, willy-nilly , and ride up with me thyself contra voluntatem et profession 'em.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: How: let me see this trick, and I'll say thou hast more
Art than a conjurer.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Dost thou joy in my advancement?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Do I love sack and ginger?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Comes my prosperity desiredly to thee?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Come forfeitures to a usurer, fees to an officer, punks to an host, and pigs to a parson desiredly? why then la.

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: Will the report of a widow of four hundred a year boy, make thee leap, and sing, and dance, and come to thy place again.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Wilt thou command me now? I am thy spirit, conjure me into any shape.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
I ha' brought her from her friends, turned back the horses by a slight, not so much as one amongst her six men, goodly large yeomanly fellows, will she trust with this her purpose: by this light all unmanned; regardless of her state, neglectful of vainglorious ceremony, all for my love; o 'tis a
fine little voluble tongue mine host, that wins a widow.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No 'tis a tongue with a great t my boy that wins a widow.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Now sir, the case stands thus, good mine host, if thou lovest my happiness assist me.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Command all my beasts ith' house.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Nay that's not all neither, prithee take truce with thy joy, and listen to me, thou knowest I have a wealthy uncle i'th city, somewhat the wealthier by my follies; the report of this fortune well and cunningly carried, might be a means to draw some goodness from the usuring rascal, for I have put her in hope already of some estate that I have either in land or money: now if I be found true in neither, what may I expect but a sudden breach of our love, utter dissolution of the match, and confusion of my fortunes for ever.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Wilt thou but trust the managing of thy business with me?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: With thee? why will I desire to thrive in my purpose? will I hug four hundred a year? I that know the misery of nothing? will that man wish a rich widow, that has ne'er a hole to put his head in? with thee mine host, why believe it, sooner with thee then with a covey of counsellors?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thank you for your good report i'faith sir, and if I stand you not instead, why then let an host come off hic et haec hostis, a deadly enemy to dice, drink, and venery; come where's this widow?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Hard at Parke-end.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I'll be her servingman for once.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why there we let off together, keep full time, my thoughts were striking then just the same number.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I knew't, shall we then see our merry days again?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Our merry nights — which ne'er shall be more seen.

div.stage: Enter at several doors, old Lucre, and old Hoord, gentlemen coming between them, to pacify 'em.

sp.speaker: Lampr.
sp.p: Nay good master lucre, and you master Hoord ▪ anger is the wind which you ' re both too much troubled with all.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Shall my adversary thus daily affront me, ripping up the old wound of our malice, which three summers could not close up, into which wound the very sight of him, drops scalding lead instead of balsamum.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why Hoord, Hoord, Hoord, Hoord, Hoord; may I not pass in the state of quietness to mine own house, answer me to that , before witness, and why? I'll refer the cause to honest even-minded gentlemen, or require the mere indifferences of the law, to decide this matter, I got the purchase, true; was't not any man's case? yes, will a wiseman stand as a bawd, whilst another wipes his nose of the bargain, no, I answer no in that case.

sp.speaker: Lampr.
sp.p: Nay sweet master lucre.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Was it the part of a friend: no, rather of a Jew, mark what I say, when I had beaten the bush to the last bird, or as I may term it, the price to a pound, then like a cunning usurer to come in the evening of the bargain, and glean all my hopes in a minute, to enter as it were at the backdoor of the purchase, for thou ne'er camest the right way by it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hast thou the conscience to tell me so, without any impeachment to thyself?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Thou that canst defeat thy own nephew, lucre, lap his lands into bonds, and take the extremity of thy kindred's forfeitures because he's a rioter, a waste-thrift, a brothel-master, and so forth — what may a stranger expect from thee, but vulnera delacerata, as the poet says, delacerate dealing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Upbraid'st thou me with nephew? is all imputation laid upon me? what acquaintance have I with his follies, if he riot, 'tis he must want it, if he surfeit, 'tis he must feel it:
if he drab it, 'tis he must lie by't, what's this to me?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: What's all to thee? nothing, nothing; such is the gulf of thy desire, and the wolf of thy conscience, but be assured old pecunious lucre, if ever fortune so bless me, that I may be at leisure to vex thee, or any means so favour me, that I may have opportunity to mad thee, I will pursue it with that flame of hate, that spirit of malice, unrepressed wrath, that I will blast thy comforts.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Nay master Hoord you ' re a wise gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: I will so cross thee,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And I thee.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: So without mercy fret thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So monstrously oppose thee?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Dost scoff at my just anger? o that I had as much power as usury has over thee?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then thou wouldst have as much power as the devil has over thee.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Toad!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Aspic.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Serpent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Viper.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Nay gentlemen, than we must divide you perforce.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: When the fire grows too unreasonable hot, there's no better way than to take of the wood.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A word good signior.

sp.speaker: Mony.
sp.p: How now, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: 'Tis given me to understand, that you are a rival of mine in the love of mistress Joyce, master hoards niece: say me I, say me no.

sp.speaker: Mony.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Then look to yourself, you cannot live long, I'm practising every morning, a month hence I'll challenge you.

sp.speaker: Monyt.
sp.p: Give me your hand upon't there's my pledge I'll meet you?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O, o — what reason had you for that sir to strike before the mouth, you knew I was not ready for you, and that made you so crank, I am not such a coward to strike again I warrant you, my ear has the law of her side for it burns horribly, I will teach him to strike a naked face, the longest day of his life, slid it shall cost me some money, but I'll bring this box into the chancery.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Fear you nothing sir, I have lodged her in a house of credit I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Hast thou the writings?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Firm sir

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Prithee stay, and behold two the most prodigious rascals that ever slipped into the shape of men, Dampit sirrah, and young gulf, his fellow caterpillar.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Dampit? sure I have heard of that Dampit.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Heard of him? why man he that has lost both his ears, may hear of him, a famous infamous trampler of time; his own phrase: note him well, that Dampit sirrah, he in the uneven beard, and the serge cloak, is the most notorious, usuring, blasphemous, atheistical, brothel, vomiting rascal, that we have in these latter times now extant, whose first beginning was the stealing of a masty dog from a farmer's house.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He looked as if he would obey the commandment well, when he began first with stealing.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: True, the next town he came at, he set the dogs together by'th ears.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A sign he should follow the law by my faith.

sp.speaker: Ʋʋitt.
sp.p:
So it followed indeed, and being destitute of all fortunes, staked his masty against a noble, and by great fortune his dog had the day, how he made it up ten shillings I know not, but his own boast is, that he came to town but
with ten shillings in his purse, and now is credibly worth ten thousand pound?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: How the devil came he by it?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How the devil came he not by it, if you put in the devil once riches come with a vengeance, has been a trampler of the law sir, and the devil has a care of his footmen, the rogue has spied me now, he nibbled me finely once too; a pox search you, o master Dampit, the very loins of thee; cry you mercy master gulf, you walk so low I promise you I saw you not sir?

sp.speaker: Gulf.
sp.p: He that walks low walks safe, the poets tell us.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And nigher hell by a foot and a half than the rest of his fellows, but my old Harry.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: My sweet Theodorus?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: 'Twas a merry world when thou cam'st to town with ten shillings in thy purse.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: And now worth ten thousand pound my boy, report it, Harry Dampit, a trampler of time, say, he would be up in a morning, and be here with his serge gown, dashed up to the hams in a cause, have his feet stink about Westminster hall and come home again, see the galleons, the galleasses the great armadoes of the law, than there be hoys and petty vessels, oars and scullers of the time, there be picklocks of the time too, then would I be here, I would trample up and down like a mule; now to the judges, may it please your reverend — honourable fatherhoods: then to my counsellor, may it please your worshipful patience, then to the examiner's office, may it please your mastership's gentleness, then to one of the clerks, may it please your worshipful lousiness, for I find him scrubbing in his codpiece, then to the hall again, then to the chamber again;

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And when to the cellar again?

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p:
E'en when thou wilt again; tramplers of time, motions of Fleetstreet, and visions of Holborn, here I have
fees of one, there I have fees of another, my clients come about me, the foolaminy and coxcombry of the country, I still trashed and trotted for other men's causes, thus was poor Harry Dampit made rich by others laziness, who, though they would not follow their own suits, I made 'em follow me with their purses.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Didst thou so old Harry?

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: Ay, and I souc'st 'em with bills of charges i'faith, twenty pound a year have I brought in for boat-hire, and I ne'er stepped into boat in my life.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Tramplers of time.

sp.speaker: Dampit.
sp.p: Ay, tramplers of time, rascals of time, bulbeggars:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Ah thou'rt a mad old Harry? kind master gulf, I am bold to renew my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Gulf.
sp.p: I embrace it sir.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: My adversary evermore twits me with my nephew, forsooth my nephew: why may not a virtuous uncle have a dissolute nephew? what though he be a brotheler, a waste-thrift, a common surfeiter, and to conclude a beggar, must sin in him, call up shame in me: since we have no part in their follies, why should we have part in their infamies? for my strict hand towards his mortgage that I deny not, I confess I had an uncle's penworth: let me see, half in half, true, I saw neither hope of his reclaiming, nor comfort in his being, and was it not then better bestowed upon his uncle, then upon one of his ants, I need not say bawd, for every own knows what aunt stands for in the last translation now sir.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.p: There's a country servingman sir, attends to speak with your worship.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I'm at best leisure now, send him in to me;

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Bless your venerable worship.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Welcome good fellow.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He calls me thief at first sight, yet he little thinks I am an host?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's thy business with me?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Faith sir, I am sent from my mistress to any sufficient gentleman indeed, to ask advice upon a doubtful point, 'tis indifferent sir, to whom I come, for I know none, nor did my mistress direct me to any particular man, for she's as mere a stranger here as myself, only I found your worship within, and 'tis a thing I ever loved sir to be dispatched as soon as I can:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: A good blunt honesty, I like him well what is thy mistress?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Fayth a country gentlewoman and a widow sir, yesterday was the first flight of us, but now she intends to stay till a little term business be ended.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Her name I prithee?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: It runs there in the writings sir, among her lands, widow Medler?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Meddler? mass have I ne'er heard of that widow?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yes, I warrant you, have you sir, not the rich widow in Staffordshire:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Cuds me, there 'tis indeed, thou hast put me into memory, there's a widow indeed, ah that I were a bachelor again.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No doubt your worship might do much then, but she's fairly promised to a bachelor already.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ah what is he I prithee?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A country gentleman too, one whom your worship knows not I'm sure: has spent some few follies in his youth, but marriage by my faith begins to call him home, my mistress loves him sir, and love covers faults you know, one master Wit-good if ever you have heard of the gentleman:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha? Wit-good sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That's his name indeed sir; my mistress is like to bring him to a goodly seat yonder, four hundred a year by my faith,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But I pray take me with you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Ay sir ?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What countryman might this young Wit-good be?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A Leicestershire gentleman sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: My nephew, by th' mass my nephew, I'll fetch out more of this i'faith, a simple country fellow, I'll work't out of him, and is that gentleman sayst thou presently to marry her?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Faith he brought her up to town sir, has the best card in all the bunch fort, her heart: and I know my mistress will be married, ere she go down, nay I'll swear that, for she's none of those widows that will go down first, and be married after, she hates that I can tell you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: By my faith sir, she is like to have a proper gentleman and a comely, I'll give her that gift?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why does your worship know him sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know him! dos not all the world know him, can a man of such exquisite qualities be hid under a bushel?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Then your worship may save me a labour, for I had charge given me to inquire after him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Inquire of him? if I might counsel thee, thou shouldst ne'er trouble thyself further, inquire of him of no more but of me, I'll fit thee? I grant he has been youthful, but is he not now reclaimed; mark you that sir, has not your mistress think you been wanton in her youth? if men be wags, are there not women wagtails?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No doubt sir:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Does not he return wisest, that comes home whipped with his own follies.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why very true sir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: The worst report you can hear of him I can tell you is that he has been a kind gentleman, a liberal and a worthy, who but lusty Wit-good, thrice noble Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Since your worship has so much knowledge in him,
can you resolve me sir what his living might be, my duty binds me sir to have a care of my mistress estate, she has been ever a good mistress to me though I say it, many wealthy suitors has she nonsuited for his sake, yet though her love be so fixed, a man cannot tell whether his non-performance may help to remove it sir; he makes us believe he has lands and living.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who young master Wit-good! why believe it he has as goodly a fine living out yonder, what do you call the place?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Nay I know not i'faith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hum, see like a beast if I have not forgotten the name, puh, and out yonder again, goodly grown woods and fair meadows , pax on't, I can ne'er hit of that place neither, he; why hes Wit-good of Wit-good-hall, he, an unknown thing.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Is he so sir, to see how rumor will alter, trust me sir we heard once he had no lands, but all lay mortgaged to an uncle he has in town here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Push, 'tis a tale, 'tis a tale.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I can assure you sir 'twas credibly reported to my mistress.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why do you think i'faith he was ever so simple to mortgage his lands to his uncle? or his uncle so unnatural to take the extremity of such a mortgage.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That was my saying still sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Puh, ne'er think it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yet that report goes currant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay then you urge me,
Cannot I tell that best that am his uncle,

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: How sir! what have I done.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why how now in a swoon, man .

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Is your worship his uncle sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Can that be any harm to you sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
I do beseech your sir do me the favour to conceal it, what a beast was I to utter so much: pray sir do me the kindness to keep it in, I shall have my coat pulled o'er my
ears, an't should be known, for the truth is an't please your worship, to prevent much rumour and many suitors, they intend to be married very suddenly and privately.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: And dost thou think it stands with my judgement to do them injury, must I needs say the knowledge of this marriage comes from thee? am I a fool at fifty four? do I lack subtlety now that have got all my wealth by it? there's a leash of angels for thee, come let me woe thee, speak where lie they?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: So I might have no anger sir —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Passion of me not a jot, prithee come.

sp.speaker: Hostis.
sp.p: I would not have it known it came by my means, —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why am I a man of wisdom?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I dare trust your worship sir, but I'm a stranger to your house, and to avoid all intelligencers I desire your worship's ear.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This fellow's worth a matter of trust — come sir, why now thou'rt an honest lad: ah sirrah nephew?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Please you sir now I have begun with your worship when shall I attend, for your advice upon that doubtful point, I must come warily now.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Tut, fear thou nothing, to morrow's evening shall resolve the doubt.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: The time shall cause my attendance.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: Fare thee well: there's more true honesty in such a country servingman, then in a hundred of our cloak companions, I may well call 'em companions, for since blue coats have been turned into cloaks, we can scarce know the man from the master — George —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Anon sir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: List hither, — keep the place secret, commend me to my nephew, I know no cause tell him but he might see his uncle?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And do you hear sir, take heed you use him with respect and duty.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Here's a strange alteration, one day he must be turned out like a beggar, and now he must be called in like a knight!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah sirrah, that rich widow, 400. a year, beside I here she lays claim to a title of a hundred more, this falls unhappily that he should bear a grudge to me now being likely to prove so rich, what is't trow that he makes me a stranger for? hum, I hope he has not so much wit to apprehend that I cozened him, he deceives me then? good heaven, who would have thought, it would ever have come to this pass, — yet he's a proper gentleman i'faith, give him his due — marry that's his mortgage, but that I never mean to give him, I'll make him rich enough in words if that be good, and if it come to a piece of money I will not greatly stick fort, there may be hope some of the widow's lands too, may one day fall upon me if things be carried wisely: now sir, where is he?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: He desires your worship to hold him excused, he has such weighty business it commands him wholly from all men.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Were those my nephew's words?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: When men grow rich they grow proud too, I perceive that, he would not have sent me such an answer once within this twelvemonth, see what 'tis when a man's come to his lands, return to him again sir, tell him his uncle desires his company for an hour ▪ I'll trouble him but an hour say, 'tis for his own good tell him, and do you hear sir, put worship upon him, go too, do as I bid you, he's like to be a gentleman of worship very shortly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: This is good sport i'faith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Troth he uses his uncle, discourteously now, can he tell what I may do for him, goodness may come from me in a minute that comes not in seven year again, he knows my humour I am not so usually good, 'tis no small thing that draws kindness from me, he may know that, and he will; the chief cause that invites me to do him most good, is the sudden astonishing of
old Hoord my adversary, how pale his malice will look at my nephew's advancement, with what a dejected spirit he will behold his fortunes, whom but last day, he proclaimed rioter, penurious makeshift, despised brothel master; ha, ha, 'twill do me more secret joy then my last purchase, more precious comfort then all these widow's revenues, — now sir. —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: With much entreaty he's at length come sir,

sp.speaker: Lu
sp.p: O nephew, let me salute you sir, your welcome nephew

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Uncle I thank you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You've a salt nephew, your a stranger here, well heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Of what sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ha, we can hear.
You might have known your uncle's house i'faith, you and your widow, go too, you were too blame; if I may tell you so without offence.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How could you hear of that sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O pardon me,
It was your will to have it kept from me I perceive now.

sp.speaker: Ʋʋit.
sp.p: Not for any defect of love I protest uncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O 'twas unkindness nephew, fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: I am sorry you take it in that sense sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Puh, you cannot colour it i'faith nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will you but hear what I can say in my just excuse sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes faith will I, and welcome.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You that know my danger ith' city sir so well, how great my debts are, and how extreme my creditors could not out of your pure judgement sir, have wished us hither.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mass a firm reason indeed,

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Else my uncle's house, why 'thad been the only make — match. —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay and thy credit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My credit? nay my countenance, push, nay I know uncle you would have wrought it so by your wit you would have made her believe in time the whole house had been mine —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I and most of the goods too —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: La you there; well, let 'em all prate what they will there's nothing like the bringing of a widow to ones uncle's house.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay let nephews be ruled as they list, they shall find their uncle's house, the most natural place when all's done.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: There they may be bold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Life, they may do any thing there man, and fear neither beadle nor sumner, an uncle's house! A very coal-harbour? Sirrah, I'll touch thee near now, hast thou so much interest in thy widow, that by a token thou couldst presently send for her?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth I think I can uncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go too, let me see that?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Pray command one of your men hither uncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: George?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Attend my nephew? I love a life to prattle with a rich widow, 'tis pretty methinks when our tongues go together, and then to promise much and perform little; I love that sport a life i'faith, yet I am in the mood now to do my nephew some good, if he take me handsomely: what have you dispatched?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I ha' sent sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yet I must condemn you of unkindness nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heaven forbid uncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes faith must I; say your debts be many, your creditors importunate, yet the kindness of a thing is all nephew, you might have sent me close word on't, without the least danger, or prejudice to your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth I confess it uncle, I was too blame there, but indeed my intent was to have clapped it up suddenly, and so have broke forth like a joy to my friends, and a wonder to the world, beside there's a trifle of a forty pound matter toward the setting of me forth, my friends should ne'er have known on't, I meant to make shift for that myself ▪

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How nephew? let me not hear such a word again, I beseech you, — shall I be beholding to you?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To me alas, what do you mean uncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I charge you upon my love: you trouble nobody but myself.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You've no reason for that uncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Troth I'll ne'er be friends with you while you live and you do.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Nay and you say so uncle, here's my hand, I will not do't —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why well said, there's some hope in thee when thou wilt be ruled, I'll make it up fifty faith, because I see thee so reclaimed; peace, here comes my wife with same her tother husband's son.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Good aunt —

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Cozen Wit-good? I rejoice in my salute, your most welcome to this noble city governed with the sword in the scabbard,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And the wit in the pommel, good master same freedom I return the salute.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: By the mass she's coming wife, let me see now how thou wilt entertain her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I hope I am not to learn sir, to entertain a widow, 'tis not so long ago since I was one myself?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Uncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She's come indeed?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My uncle was desirous to see you widow, and I presumed to invite you.

sp.speaker: Curti.
sp.p: The presumption was nothing master Wit-good, is this yours uncle sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Marry am I sweet widow, and his good uncle he shall find me, I by this smack that I give thee, thou'rt welcome, wife, bid the widow welcome the same way again.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I am a gentleman now too, by my father's occupation, and I see no reason but I may kiss a widow by my father's copy, truly I think the charter is not against it, surely these are the words, the son once a gentleman, may revel it, though his father were a dauber, 'tis about the 15 page, — I'll to her —

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: You're not very busy now, a word with thee sweet widow —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Coads-nigs, I was never so disgraced, since the hour my mother whipped me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Beside, I have no child of mine own to care for, she's my second wife, old, passed bearing, clap sure to him widow, he's like to be my heir I can tell you?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is he so sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He knows it already and the knaves proud on't, jolly rich widows have been offered him here ith' city, great merchant's wives, and do you think he would once look upon 'em? forsooth he'll none, you are beholding to him ith' country then; ere we could be, nay, I'll hold a wager widow if he were once known to be in town, he would be presently sought after, nay and happy were they, that could catch him first.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I think so?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O, there would be such running to and fro widow, he should not pass the streets for 'em: he'd be taken up in one great house or other presently, fah, they know he has it and must have it; you see this house here widow, this house and all comes to him, goodly rooms ready furnished, ceiled with plaster of Paris, and all hung above with cloth of arras. Nephew!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Sir —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Show the widow your house, carry her into all the rooms, and bid her welcome, — you shall see widow — nephew? — strike all sure above and thou beest a good boy — ah —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alas sir, I know not how she would take it:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The right way I warrant tee, a pox, art an ass, would I were in thy stead, get you up, I am a shamed of you, so: let 'em agree as they will now? many a match has been struck up in my house a this fashion, let 'em try all manner of ways still there's nothing like an uncle's house to strike the stroke in, — I'll hold my wife in talk a little, now ginnee; your son there goes a-wooing to a poor gentlewoman but of a 1000. portion, see my nephew, a lad of less hope, strikes at four hundred a year in good rubbish .

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Well we must do as we may sir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p:
I'll have his money ready told for him, again he come down, let me see too, by'th mass I must present the widow with some jewel, a good piece a plate or such a device, 'twill
hearten her on well, I have a very fair standing cup, and a good high standing cup will please a widow above all other pieces.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Do you mock us with your nephew, I have a plot in my head son, i'faith husband to cross you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is it a tragedy plot, or a comedy plot, good mother.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: 'Tis a plot shall vex him, I charge you of my blessing son Sam, that you presently withdraw the action of your love from master hoards niece.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How mother.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Nay I have a plot in my head i'faith, here take this chain of gold and this fair diamond, dog me the widow home to her lodging, and at thy best opportunity fasten 'em both upon her — nay I have a reach, I can tell you thou art known what thou art son among the right worshipful; all the twelve companies.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Truly I thank 'em for it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: He, he's a scab to thee, and so certify her, thou hast two hundred a year of thyself, beside thy good parts — a proper person and a lovely, if I were a widow I could find in my heart to have thee myself, son, ay, from 'em all.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thank you for your good will mother, but in deed I had rather have a stranger: and if I woe her not in that violent fashion, that I will make her be glad to take these gifts ere I leave her, let me never be called the heir of your body.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Nay I know there's enough in you son if you once come to put it forth.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I'll quickly make a bolt, or a shaft on't.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Faith master Hoord, I have bestowed many months in the suit of your niece, such was the dear love I ever bore to her virtues, but since she hath so extremely denied me, I am to lay out for my fortunes else where.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Heaven forbid but you should fir, I ever told you my niece, stood otherwise affected.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I must confess you did sir, yet in regard of my great loss of time, and the zeal with which I sought your niece, shall I desire one favour of your worship.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: In regard of those two 'tis hard but you shall sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I shall rest grateful, 'tis not full 3. hours sir, since the happy rumour of a rich country widow came to my hearing.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How a rich country widow?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Four hundred a year landed.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Yea?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Most firm sir, and I have learned her lodging, here my suit begins sir, if I might but entreat your worship to be a countenance for me, and speak a good word: for your words will pass, I nothing doubt, but I might set fair for the widow, nor shall your labour sir end altogether in thanks, two hundred angels —

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: So, so, what suitors has she?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There lies the comfort sir, the report of her is yet but a whisper, and only solicited by young riotous Wit-good, nephew to your mortal adversary.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ha? art certain he's her suitor?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Most certain sir, and his uncle very industrious to beguile the widow, and make up the match!

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: So? very good?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now sir you know this young Wit-good is a spendthrift — dissolute fellow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A very rascal:

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A midnight surfeiter.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: The spume of a brothel-house.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: True sir? which being well told in your worship's phrase, may both heave him out of her mind, and drive a fair way for me to the widow's affections.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Attend me about 5.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: With my best care sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Fool thou hast left thy treasure with a thief, to trust a widower with a suit in love, happy revenge I hug thee, I have not only the means laid before me, extremely to cross my adversary, and confound the last hopes of his nephew, but thereby to enrich my state; augment my revenues, and build mine own fortunes greater, ha, ha.
I'll mar your phrase, o'erturn your flatteries,
undo your windings, policies, and plots,
Fall like a secret and dispatchful plague on your secured comforts, why I am able to buy 3. of lucer, thrice outbid him, let my out-monies be reckoned and all.

sp.p: I am glad of this news.
So are we by my faith.
Young Wit-good will be a gallant again now.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Peace?
I promise you master cockpit she's a mighty rich widow.
Why have you ever heard of her.
Who widow Medler, she lies open to much rumour.
Four hundred a year they say in very good land.
Nay take't of my word if you believe that, you believe the least.
And to see how close he keeps it.
O sir there's policy in that to prevent better suitors.
He owes me a hundred pound, and I protest I ne'er looked for a penny.
He little dreams of our coming, he'll wonder to see his creditors upon him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Good, his creditors, I'll follow, this makes for me, all know the widow's wealth and 'tis well known, I can estate her fairly, I and will.
In this one chance shines a twice happy fate,
I both deject my foe, and raise my state.

div.head: Incipit act. 3.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Why alas, my creditors? could you find no other time to undo me but now, rather your malice appears in this then the justness of the debt.
Master Wit-good I have forborn my money long.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I pray speak low sir, what do you mean?
We hear you are to be married suddenly to a rich country widow?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
What can be kept so close but you creditors here on't, well, 'tis a lamentable state, that our chiefest afflicters should first
hear of our fortunes, why this is no good course i'faith sirs, if ever you have hope to be satisfied, why do you seek to confound the means that should work it, there's neither piety, no nor policy in that, shine favourably now, why I may rise and spread again, to your great comforts.
He says true i'faith.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Remove me now, and I consume for ever.
Sweet gentleman?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How can it thrive which from the sun you sever.
It cannot indeed?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: O then show patience, I shall have enough to satisfy you all.
Ay, if we could be content a shame take us.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: For look you, I am but newly sure yet to the widow, and what a rend might this discredit make: within these 3. days will I bind you lands for your securities.

sp.l: No, good master Wit-good,
Would 'twere as much as we dare trust you with?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know you have been kind, however now either by wrong report, or false incitement your gentleness is injured, in such a state as this a man cannot want foes.
sp.l: If on the sudden he begin to rise,
No man that lives can count his enemies.
You had some intelligence I warrant ye, from an ill-willer.

sp.p: Faith we heard you brought up a rich widow sir, and were suddenly to marry her.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Ay, why there it was, I knew 'twas so, but since you are so well resolved of my faith towards you, let me be so much favoured of you, I beseech you all —

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O, it shall not need i'faith sir, —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: As to lie still a while, and bury my debts in silence, till I be fully possessed of the widow, for the truth is, I may tell you as my friends —

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O — oh — oh —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I am to raise a little money in the city, towards the setting forth of myself, for mine own credit, and your comfort, now if my former debts should be divulged, all hope of my proceedings were quite extinguished!

Do you hear sir, I may deserve your custom hereafter, pray let my money be accepted before a stranger's, here's forty
pound I received as I came to you, if that may stand you in any stead make use on't, nay pray sir, 'tis at your service —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You do so ravish me with kindness, that I'm constrained, to play the maid and take it?
Let none of them see it I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Fah —
I hope I shall be first in your remembrance after the marriage rites.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Believe it firmly.
So, what do you walk sirs?
I go — take no care sir for money to furnish you, within this hour I'll send you sufficient: come master cockpit we both stay for you.

I ha' lost a ring i'faith, I'll follow you presently — but you shall find it sir, I know your youth and expenses have disfurnished you of all jewels, there's a ruby of twenty pound price sir, bestow it upon your widow, — what man, 'twill call up her blood to you, beside if I might so much work with you, I would not have you beholding to those bloodsuckers for any money.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Not I believe it.
They're a brace of cutthroats?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know 'em.
Send a note of all your wants to my shop and I'll supply you instantly.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Say you so, why here's my hand then no man living shall do't but thyself.
Shall I carry it away from 'em both then.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: i'faith shalt thou?
Troth then I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Wit .
sp.p: Welcome good master cockpit!

Ha, ha, ha? why is not this better now, then lying a-bed , I perceive there's nothing conjures up wit sooner than poverty, and nothing lays it down sooner than wealth and lechery? this has some savour yet, o that I had the mortgage from mine uncle as sure in possession as these trifles, I would forswear brothel at noon day, and muscadine and eggs at midnight.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Master Wit-good? where are you?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Holla.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Rich news!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Would 'twere all in plate,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: There's some in chains and jewels, I am so haunted with suitors master Wit-good, I know not which to dispatch first.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You have the better term by my faith

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Among the number, one master Hoard an ancient gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Upon my life my uncle's adversary.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: It may well hold so, for he rails on you,
Speaks shamefully of him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: As I could wish it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I first denied him, but so cunningly,
It rather promised him assured hopes,
Than any loss of labour.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Excellent,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I expect him every hour, with gentlemen,
With whom he labours to make good his words,
To approve you riotous, your state consumed, your uncle, —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Wench, make up thy own fortunes now, do thyself a good turn once in thy days, he's rich in money, movables, and lands, — marry him, he's an old doting fool, and that's worth all, marry him, 'twould be a great comfort to me to see thee do well i'faith, — marry him, 'twould ease my conscience well to see thee well bestowed, I have a care of thee i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Thanks sweet master Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I reach at farther happiness; first I am sure it can be no harm to thee, and there may happen goodness to me by it, prosecute it well, let's send up for out wits, now we require their best and most pregnant assistance!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Step in, I think I hear 'em.

div.stage: Enter Hoord and gentlemen with the host, — servingman.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Art thou the widow's man, by my faith sh' as a company of proper men then.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I am the worst of six sir, good enough for blue-coats.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Hark hither, I hear say thou art in most credit with her.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Not so sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Come, come, thou'rt modest, there's a brace of royals, prithee help me to'th speech of her.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: I'll do what I may sir always saving myself harmless.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Go too do't I say, thou shalt hear better from me.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Is not this a better place than 5. Mark a year standing wages; say a man had but 3. such clients in a day, methinks he might make a poor living on't, beside I was never brought up with so little honesty, to refuse any man's money never; what gulls there are a this side the world, now know I the widow's mind, none but my young master comes in her clutches, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Now my dear gentlemen stand firmly to me, you know his follies, and my worth.
We do sir.
But master Hoord, are you sure he is not ith' house now?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Upon my honesty ▪ I chose this time,
A purpose, fit, the spendthrift is abroad,
Assist me: here she comes . now my sweet widow,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Y' are welcome master Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, dispatch,
I am come widow, to prove those my words,
Neither of envy sprung nor of false tongs,
But such as their deserts and actions,
Do merit and bring forth, all which these gentlemen well known and better reputed will confess.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
How my affections may dispose of me,
But surely if they find him so desertless,
They'll have that reason to withdraw themselves.
And therefore gentlemen I do entreat you,
As you are fair in reputation,
And in appearing form so shine in truth;
I am a widow and alas you know,
Soon overthrown, 'tis a very small thing,
That we withstand, our weakness is so great,
Be partial unto neither, but deliver,
Without affection your opinion,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And that will drive it home,

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: Nay I beseech your silence master Hoord,
You are a party.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Widow? not a word!

sp.l: The better first to work you to belief,
Know neither of us owe him flattery,
Nor tother malice, but unbribed censure,
So help us our best fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It suffics?

sp.l: That Wit-good is a riotous undone man,
Imperfect both in fame and in estate:
His debts wealthier than he, and executions
In wait for his due body, we'll maintain
With our best credit, and our dearest blood.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Nor land, nor living say you, pray take heed you do not wrong the gentleman?

sp.l: What we speak,
Our lives and means are ready to make good.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Alas, how soon are we poor souls beguiled!
And for his uncle. —

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let that come to me,
His uncle a severe extortioner,
A tyrant at a forfeiture, greedy of others miseries,
One that would undo his brother; nay swallow
Up his father, if he can
Within the fathoms of his conscience.
Nay believe it widow,
You had not only matched yourself to wants,
But in an evil and unnatural stock.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Follow hard, gentlemen, follow hard?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Is my love so deceived, before you all
I do renounce him, on my knees I vow
He ne'er shall marry me, —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heaven knows he never meant it?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: There, take her at the bound, —

sp.l: Then with a new and pure affection,
Behold you gentleman, grave, kind and rich:
A match worthy yourself, esteeming him,
You do regard your state.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I'll make her a jointure say.
He can join land to land, and will possess you of what you can desire.
Come widow come.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: The world is so deceitful?

sp.l: There 'tis deceitful,
Where flattery, want, and imperfection lies:
But none of these in him? push —

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Pray sir.
Come you widows are ever most backward, when you should do yourselves most good, but were it to marry a chin not worth a hair now, than you would be forward enough? come, clap hands, a match.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Withal my heart widow, thanks gentlemen,
I will deserve your labour, and thy love.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Alas, you love not widows but for wealth,
I promise you I ha' nothing sir,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Well said, widow, well said, thy love is all I seek, before these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Now I must hope the best,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: My joys are such they want to be expressed,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But master Hoord, one thing I must remember you of before these gentlemen your friends, how shall I suddenly avoid the loathed soliciting of that perjured Wit-good, and his tedious — dissembling uncle, who this very very day hath appointed a meeting for the same purpose too, where had not truth come forth I had been undone, utterly undone.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: What think you of that gentlemen.
'Twas well devised.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Hark thee widow, train out young Wit-good single, hasten him thither with thee, somewhat before the hour where at the place appointed these gentlemen and myself will wait the opportunity, when by some sleight removing him from thee we'll suddenly enter and surprise thee, carry thee away by boat to Coale-harbour, have a priest ready and there clap it up instantly, how likest it widow?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: In that it pleaseth you, it likes me well.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: I'll kiss thee for those words, come ▪ gentlemen,
Still must I live a suitor to your favours,
Still to your aid beholding.
We're engaged sir.
'Tis for our credits now to see't well ended.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: 'Tis for your honour's gentlemen; nay look to't,
Not only in joy, but I in wealth excel,
No more sweet widow, but sweet wife, farewell.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Farewell sir. —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O for more scope, I could laugh eternally,

Give you joy mistress Hoord, I promise your fortune was good forsooth, you've fell upon wealth enough, and there's young gentlemen enough can help you to the rest; now it requires our wits: carry thyself but heedfully now, and we are both —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Master Wit-good your uncle —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Cuds me, remove thyself a while, I'll serve for him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nephew, good morrow, nephew?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: The same to you kind uncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How fares the widow, does the meeting hold?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: O no question of that sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'll strike the stroke then for thee, no more days.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: The sooner the better uncle, o she's mightily followed, —

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: And yet so little rumoured.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Mightily? here comes one old gentleman, and he'll make her a jointure of three hundred a year forsooth, another wealthy suitor will estate his son in his life time, and make him weigh down the widow, here a merchant's son will possess, her with no less than three goodly lordships at once, which were all pawns to his father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Peace nephew let me hear no more of 'em, it mads me, thou shalt prevent 'em all, no words to the widow of my coming hither, let me see, 'tis now upon nine, before twelve. Nephew we will have the bargain struck, we will faith boy.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: O my precious uncle.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Niece, sweet niece, prithee have a care to my house, I leave all to thy discretion, be content to dream a while, I'll have a husband for thee shortly, put that care upon me wench, for in choosing wives and husbands I am only fortunate, I have that gift given me.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: But 'tis not likely you should choose for me,
Since nephew to your chiefest enemy:
Is he whom I affect, but o forgetful,
Why dost thou flatter thy affections so:
With name of him, that for a widow's bed,
Neglects thy purer love, can in be so?
Or does report dissemble: how now sir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A letter with which came a private charge.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Therein I thank your care — I know this hard,

body.p: Dearer than sight, what the world reports of me yet believe not, rumour will alter shortly, be thou constant, I am still the same that I was in love, and I hope to be the same in fortunes.

sp.l: I am resolved, no more shall fear or doubt,
Raise their pale powers to keep affection out.

div.stage: Enter with a drawer, Hoord, and two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: You're very welcome gentlemen, Dick show those gentlemen the pomegranate there, —

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Hist —

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Up those stairs gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Pist drawer, —

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Anon sir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Prithee ask at the bar, if a gentlewoman came not in lately?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: William at the bar did you see any gentlewoman come in lately, speak you ay, speak you no.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: No, none came in yet but mistress Florence.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: He says none came in yet sir, but one mistress Florence.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What is that Florence? A widow!

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Yes a Dutch widow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: That's an English drab sir, give your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A merry knave i'faith, I shall remember a Dutch widow the longest day of my life.
Did not I use most art to win the widow.
You shall pardon me for that sir, master Hoord knows I took her at best vantage.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What's that sweet gentlemen, what's that?
He will needs bear me down that his art only, wrought with the widow most.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: O you did both well gentlemen, you did both well, I thank you.
I was the first that moved her.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: You were i'faith.
But it was I that took her at the bound.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ay, that was you, faith gentlemen, 'tis right.
I boasted least, but 'twas I joined their hands,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: By'th mass I think he did, you did all well gentlemen, you did all well, contend no more:
Come you rooms fittest:

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: True 'tis next the door?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Your very welcome, please you to walk up stairs clothes laid sir.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Up stairs! troth I am weary master Wit-good

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Rest yourself here a while widow, we'll have a cup of muscadine in this little room.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: A cup of muscadine, you shall have the best sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: But do you hear sirrah.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Do you call, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: What is there provided for dinner

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I cannot readily tell you sir, if you please, you may go into the kitchen and see yourself sir, many gentlemen of worship do use to do it, I assure you sir?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A pretty familiar priggin rascal, he has his part without book?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Against you are ready to drink to me, widow, I'll be present to pledge you.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Nay I commend your care, 'tis done well of you? ass what have I forgotten.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What mistress?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I slipped my wedding ring off when I washed, and left it at my lodging, prithee run, I shall be sad without it, so, he's gone! — boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon forsooth?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come hither sirrah, learn secretly if one master Hoard an ancient gentleman be about house?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I heard such a one named.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I be do thy commendations?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O you come well: away, to boat, be gone.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Thus wise-men are revenged give two for one.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I must request you sir, to show extraordinary care, my uncle comes with gentlemen his friends, and 'tis upon a making?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Is it so?
I'll give a special charge good master Wit-good, may I be bold to see her?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Who he widow?
Withal my heart i'faith, I'll bring you to her?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: If she be a Staffordshire gentlewoman, 'tis much if I know her not, —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How now, boy, drawer.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Hie?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Do you call sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Went the gentlewoman up that was here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Up sir? she went out sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Out sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Out sir: one master Hoard with a guard of gentlemen carried her out at backdoor, a pretty while since sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Hoord, death and darkness, Hoord.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: The devil of ring I can find?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How now, what news, where's the widow?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: My mistress? is she not here sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: More madness yet.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: She sent me for a ring.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: A plot, a plot: to boat she's stole away.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Follow, inquire, old Hoord my uncle's adversary —

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Nephew, what's that?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Thrice miserable wretch.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: The widow's born away sir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Ha, passion of me, a heavy welcome gentlemen.
The widow gone?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who durst attempt it?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Who but old Hoord, my uncle's adversary?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Vvitt.
sp.p: With his confederates.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hoord, my deadly enemy, gentlemen stand to me,
I will not bear it, 'tis in hate of me,
That villain seeks my shame, nay thrifts my blood, he owes me mortal malice,
I'll spend my wealth on this despiteful plot,
Ere he shall cross me and my nephew thus.

sp.speaker: Ʋʋit.
sp.p: So maliciously.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How now you treacherous rascal?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That's none of my name sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Poor soul he knew not on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'm sorry, I see then 'twas a mere plot.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I traced 'em nearly. —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: And hear for certain, they have taken Coleharbour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The devil's sanctuary,
They shall not rest, I'll pluck her from his arms,
Kind and dear gentlemen, if ever I had seat within your breasts —
No more good sir, it is a wrong to us,
To see you injured in a cause so just:
We'll spend our lives, but we will right our friends,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Honest, and kind, come, we have delayed too long,
Nephew take comfort; a just cause is strong.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That's all my comfort uncle, ha, ha, ha.
Now may events fall luckily, and well,
He that ne'er strives, says wit shall ne'er excel.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: When did I say my prayers? In anno 88. when the great Armado was coming, and in anno. 99. when the great thundering and lighting was I prayed heartily then i'faith, to overthrow poouyes new buildings, I knelt by my great iron chest I remember.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Master Dampit, one may hear you, before they see you, you keep sweet hour's master Dampit, we were all a-bed 3 hours ago.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Audry.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: O you're a fine gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So I am i'faith, and a fine scholar, do you use to go to bed bed, so early Audry?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Call you this early master Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why is't not one of clock ith' morning is not that early enough? fetch me a glass of fresh-beer.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Here, I have warmed your nightcap for you master Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Draw it on then — I am very weak truly, I have not eaten so much as the bulk of an egg these 3. days.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You have drunk the more master Dampit,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You might, and you would master Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I answer you I cannot, hold your prating, you prat too much, and understand too little, are you answered, — give me a glass of bear.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: May I ask you how you do master Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: How do I? i'faith naught.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I ne'er knew you do otherwise,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I eat not one pen'orth of bread these 2. years, give me a glass of fresh beer, — I am not sick, nor I am not well. —

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Take this warm napkin about your neck sir, whilst I help to make you unready.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: How now Audrie-prater, with your scurvy devices, what say you now?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: What say I master Dampit? I say nothing but that you are very weak,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Faith thou hast more coney catching devices then all London?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Why master Dampit I never deceived you in all my life?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why was that? because I never did trust thee.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: I care not what you say master Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hold thy prating, I answer thee, thou art a beggar, a quean, and a bawd: are you answered.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Fie master Dampit, a gentleman and have such words.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why thou base drudge of infortunity, thou kitchen-stuff drab of beggary, roguery and coxcombry, thou cavern-fed quean of foolery, knavery and bawdreaminy, I'll tell thee what, I will not give a louse for thy fortunes:

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: No, master Dampit, and there's a gentleman comes a-wooing to me, and he doubts nothing but that you will get me from him:

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Ay, if I would either have thee or lie with thee for two thousand pound, would I might be damned, why thou base impudent quean of foolery, flattery, and coxcombry, are you answered?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Come will you rise and go to bed sir?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Rise, and go to bed too Audry? how does mistress Proserpine?

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: Fooh —

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: She's as fine a philosopher of a stinkard's wife, as any within the liberties, — fah, fah Audry:

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: How now master Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie upon't, what a choice of stinks here is, what hast thou done Audry fie upon't, here's a choice of stinks indeed; give me a glass of fresh beer, and then I will to bed:

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: It waits for you above sir?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Foh, I think they burn horns in Barnard's inn, if ever I smelled such an abominable stink, usury forsake me:

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: They be the stinking nails of his trampling feet, and he talks of burning of horns:

div.head: Incipit act. 4.
div.stage: Enter at coal-harbour, Hoord, the widow and gentlemen, he married now.

sp.l: Join hearts, join hands, in wedlock's bands,
Never to part, till death cleave your heart,
You shall forsake all other women,
You lords, knights, gentlemen, and yeomen.
What my tongue slips, make up with your lips.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.l: Give you joy mistress Hoord, let the kiss come about,
Who knocks? convey my little pig-eater out.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hoord?

sp.speaker: Hoor,
sp.p: Upon my life, my adversary, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hoord, open the door, or we will force it open,
Give us the widow.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Gentlemen keep 'em out.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: He comes upon his death that enters here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My friends assist me.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: He has assistants, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Tut, nor him, nor them, we in this action fear.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shall I in peace, speak one word with the widow?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Husband and gentlemen, hear me but a word.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Freely sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Let him in peaceably, you know we're sure, from any act of his.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Most true,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You may stand by and smile at his old weakness, let me alone to answer him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Content,
'Twill be good mirth i'faith, how think you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Good gullery?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Upon calm conditions let him in.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All spite and malice —

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Hear me master Lucre, so you will vow a peaceful entrance with those your friends and only exercise
Calm conference with the widow, without fury,
The passage shall receive you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I do vow it.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Then enter and talk freely, here she stands.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: O master Hoord, your spite has watched the hour, your excellent at vengeance master Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am the fool you laugh at, you are wise sir and know the seasons, well, come hither widow, why is it thus!
O you have done me infinite disgrace,
and your own credit no small injury,
Suffer mine enemy so despitefully
To bear you from my nephew, o,
I had rather half my substance had been forfeited, and begged by some starved rascal.

sp.speaker: Curti.
sp.l: Why what would you wish me do sir?
I must not overthrow my state for love,
We have too many presidents for that,
From thousands of our wealthy undone widows
One may derive some wit; I do confess,
I loved your nephew, nay I did affect him,
Against the mind and liking of my friend:
Believed his promises, lay here in hope,
Of flattered living and the boast of lands,
Coming to touch his wealth and state indeed,
It appears dross, I find him not the man,
Imperfect, mean, scarce furnished of his needs:
In words, fair lordships, in performance hovels,
Can any woman love the thing that is not?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Broke you for this?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Was it not cause too much?
Send to inquire his state, most part of it,
Lay two years mortgaged in his uncle's hands:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why say it did, you might have known my mind; I could have soon restored it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I had I but seen any such thing performed why 'twould have tied my affection and contained me in my first desires, do you think i'faith, that I could twine such a dry, oak as this, had promise in your nephew took effect:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why and there's no time past, and rather than my adversary should thus thwart my hopes, I would —

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: But you've been ever full of golden speech,
If words were lands, your nephew would be rich.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Widow, believe it I vow by my best bliss,
Before these gentlemen I will give in
The mortgage to my nephew instantly,
Before I sleep or eat.

sp.p:
We'll pawn our credit's widow, what he speaks shall
be performed in fullness.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: Nay more I will estate him
In farther blessings, he shall be my heir ,
I have no son,
I'll bind myself to that condition.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: When I shall hear this done, I shall soon yield, to reasonable terms.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the mean season,
Will you protest before these gentlemen,
To keep yourself, as you are, now at this present.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: I do protest before these gentlemen,
I will be as clear then, as I am now.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.l: I do believe you, here's your own honest servant,
I'll take him along with me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: He shall see all performed and bring you word.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: That's all I wait for.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What have you finished master Lucre? ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: So, laugh Hoord, laugh at your poor enemy, do, the wind may turn you may be laughed at too, yes marry may you sir — ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Ha, ha ha, if every man that swells in malice,
Could be revenged as happily as I:
He would choose hate, and forswear amity.
What did he say wife, prithee?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Faith spoke to ease his mind, —

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: O — oh — oh —

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You know now, little to any purpose.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: True, true, true.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: He would do mountains now.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: You've struck him dead master Hoord.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: I and his nephew desperate:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: I know't sirs I,
Never did man so crush his enemy?

div.stage: Enter Lucre with gentlemen meeting same freedom's.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My son in law,
Same freedom? where's my nephew?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O man in lamentation father?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
He thumps his breast like a gallant dicer that has lost his
doublet, and stands in's shirt to do penance:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Alas poor gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I warrant, you may hear him sigh in a still evening to your house at Highgate.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I prithee send him in.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Were it to do a greater matter, I will not stick with you sir, in regard you married my mother?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: Sweet gentlemen cheer him up, I will but fetch the mortgage, and return to you instantly.

sp.l: We'll do our best sir? — see where he comes,
E'en joyless and regardless of all form.

sp.p: Why how master Wit-good, fie, you a firm scholar, and an understanding gentleman, and give your best parts to passion.
Come fie?

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: O gentlemen! —
Sorrow of me what a sigh was there sir, nine such widows are not worth it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To be born from me by that lecher Hoord.

sp.l: That vengeance is your uncles, being done
More in despite to him, then wrong to you,
But we bring comfort now, —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I beseech you gentlemen.
Cheer thyself man, there's hope of her i'faith?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Too gladsome, to be true.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Nephew what cheer? alas poor gentleman how art thou changed? call thy fresh blood into thy cheeks again, she comes —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nothing afflicts me so much,
But that it is your adversary, uncle,
And merely plotted in despite of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I that's it mads me, spites me? I'll spend my wealth, ere he shall carry her so, because I know 'tis only to spite me, I this is it, — here nephew, before these kind gentlemen I deliver in your mortgage, my promise to the widow, see 'tis done, be wise your once more master of your own, the widow shall perceive now, you are not altogether such a beggar as the world reputes you, you can make shift to bring her to 300. a year sir.
By’r lady and that's no toy sir:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A word nephew?
Now you may certify the widow?

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: You must conceive it a right nephew now, to do you good, I am content to do this.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know it sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But your own conscience can tell I had it dear enough of you?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I that's most certain.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Much money laid out, beside many a journey to fetch the rent, I hope you'll think on't nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I were worse than a beast else i'faith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Although to blind the widow and the world I out of policy do't, yet there's a conscience nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heaven forbid else.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: When you are full possessed,
'Tis nothing to return it:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alas a thing quickly done uncle.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Well said, — you know I give it you but in trust.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Pray let me understand you rightly, uncle,
You give it me but in trust.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: That is, you trust me with it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: True, true:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: But if ever I trust you with it again, would I might be trussed up for my labour.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You can all witness gentlemen, and you sir yeoman?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: My life for yours sir now, I know my mistress's mind to well towards your nephew, let things be in preparation, and I'll train her hither in most excellent fashion:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A good old boy, — wife Ginnee?

sp.speaker: Wife,
sp.p: What's the news sir?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: The wedding days at hand, prithee sweet wife, express thy housewifery, thou'rt a fine cook I know't, thy first husband married thee out of an alderman's kitchen, go too, he raised thee for raising of paste, what, here's none but friends, most of our beginnings must be winked at, gentlemen I invite you all to my nephew's wedding against Thursday morning:
Withal our hearts, and we shall joy to see your enemy so mocked:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: He laughed at me, gentlemen, ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: He has no conscience, faith would laugh at them, they laugh at one another?
Who then can be so cruel, troth, not I,
I rather pity now, then ought envy,
I do conceive such joy in mine own happiness, I have no leisure yet, to laugh at their follies.

lg.l: Thou soul of my estate I kiss thee,
I miss life's comfort when I miss thee.
O never will we part again,
Until I leave the sight of men,
We'll never trust conscience of our kin,
Since cozenage brings that title in.

sp.p: I'll wait these 7. hours but I'll see him caught,
Faith so will I.
Hang him prodigal, he's stripped of the widow.
A my troth she's the wiser, she has made the happier choice, and I wonder of what stuff those widow's hearts are made of, that will marry unfledged boys, before comely thrumb-chinned gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: News, news news,
What boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The rioter is caught.
So, so, so, so, it warms me at the heart, I love a life to see dogs upon men; o here he comes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My last joy was so great it took away the sense of all future afflictions, what a day is here o'ercast? how soon a black tempest rises?
O we may speak with you now sir, what's become of your rich widow, I think you may cast your cap at the widow, may you not sir.
He a rich widow? who a prodigal, a daily rioter, and a nightly vomiter, he a widow of account? he a hole ith' counter.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You do well my masters, to tyrannize over misery to afflict the afflicted, 'tis a custom you have here amongst you, I would wish you never leave it and I hope you'll do as I bid you
Come, come sir, what say you extempore now to your bill of a hundred pound: a sweet debt, for frotting your doublets.
Here's mine of forty,
Here's mine of fifty.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Pray sirs , you'll give me breath.
No sir, we'll keep you out of breath still, than we shall be sure you will not run away from us.

sp.speaker: Wit.
