sp.p: Will you but hear me speak?

You shall pardon us for that sir, we know you have too fair a tongue of your own, you overcame us to lately, a shame take you, we are like to lose all that for want of witnesses, we dealt in policy then, always when we strive to be most politic we prove most coxcombs, non plus ultra. I perceive by us, were not ordained to thrive by wisdom, and therefore we must be content to be tradesmen.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Give me but reasonable time, and I protest I'll make you ample satisfaction.
Do you talk of reasonable time to us?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: 'Tis true, beasts know no reasonable time,
We must have either money or carcase.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alas what good will my carcase do you?
O 'tis a secret delight we have amongst us, we that are used to keep birds in cages, have the heart to keep men in prison, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I perceive I must crave a little more aid from my wits, do but make shift for me this once, and I'll forswear ever to trouble you in the like fashion hereafter, I'll have better employment for you, and I live. You'll give me leave my masters to make trial of my friends and raise all means I can.
That's our desires sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Master Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: O art thou come!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: May I speak one word with you in private sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: No by my faith canst thou. I am in hell here and the devils will not let me come to thee.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Do you call us devils, you shall find us Puritans bear him away, let 'em talk as they go, we'll not stand to hear 'em, ah sir, am I a devil, I shall think the better of myself as long as I live, a devil i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p:
What a sweet blessing hast thou master Hoord above a multitude, wilt thou never be thankful? how dost thou think to be blessed another time? or dost thou count this the full measure of thy happiness by my troth I think thou dost : not only a wife large in possessions, but spacious in content, she's rich, she's young, she's fair, she's wife, when I wake I think of her lands that revives me, when I go to bed, I dream of her beauty, and
that's enough for me, she's worth 4. hundred a year in her very smock, if a man knew how to use it, but the journey will be all introth into the country, to ride to her lands in state and order following my brother and other worshipful gentlemen whose companies I ha' sent down for already, to ride along with us, in their goodly decorum beards, their broad velvet cassocks, and chains of gold twice or thrice double; against which time, I'll entertain some ten men of mine own, into liveries, all of occupations or qualities, I will not keep an idle man about me, the sight of which will so vex my adversary lucre, for we'll pass by his door of purpose, make a little stand for nonce, and have our horses curvet before the window, certainly he will never endure it, but run up and hang himself presently? how now sirrah? what news? any that offer their service to me yet.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes sir, there are some ith' hall, that wait for your worship's liking, and desire to be entertained.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Are they of occupation?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: They are men fit for your worship sir.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: Sayst so? send 'em all in! — to see ten men ride after me in watchet liveries with orange-tawny capes, 'twill cut his comb i'faith, how now? of what occupation are you sir.

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.p: A tailor, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: A tailor, o very good, you shall serve to make all the liveries — what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: A barber sir.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: A barber very needful, you shall shave all the house, and if need require stand for a reaper ith' summer time, — you sir?

sp.speaker: Perfumer
sp.p: A perfumer?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I smelled you before, perfumers of all men had need carry themselves uprightly, for if they were once knaves they would be smelled out quickly, — to you sir?

sp.speaker: Fawl.
sp.p: A falconer an't please your worship —

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Sa ho, sa ho, sa ho — and you sir?

sp.speaker: Huntsman
sp.p: A huntsman sir.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p:
There boy, there boy, there boy? I am not so old but I have pleasant days to come, I promise you my masters I take such a good liking to you, that I entertain you all, I put you already into my countenance, and you shall be shortly in my livery? but especially you two my jolly falconer, and
my bonny huntsman, we shall have most need of you at my wife's manor-houses ith' country, there's goodly parks and champion-grounds for you, we shall have all our sports within ourselves, all the gentlemen ath' country shall be beholding to us and our pastimes:

sp.speaker: Faul:
sp.p: And we'll make you worship admire sir:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Sayst thou so do but make me admire, and thou shalt want for nothing, — my tailor?

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.p: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Go presently in hand with the liveries.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: My barber.

sp.speaker: Barber
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Make 'em all trim fellows, louse 'em well, especially my huntsman, and cut all their beards of the Polonian fashion: my perfumer:

sp.speaker: Perfumer
sp.p: Under your nose sir:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Cast a better savour upon the knaves, to take away the scent of my tailor's feet, and my barber's lotium-water:

sp.speaker: P●r:
sp.p: It shall be carefully performed sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: But you my falconer and huntsman, the welcom'st men alive i'faith:

sp.speaker: Huntsman
sp.p: And we'll show you that sir, shall deserve your worship's favour?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I prithee show me that: go you knaves all, and wash your lungs ith' buttery, go — byth' mass, and well remembered, I'll ask my wife that question, wife, mistress Jane Hoord!

sp.speaker: Curt:
sp.p: Sir? would you with me.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I would but know sweet wife, which might stand best to thy liking, to have the wedding dinner kept here or ith' country?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Hum? faith sir 'twould like me better here, here you were married, here let all rites be ended.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Could a marquess give a better answer? Hoord bear thy head aloft, thou'st a wife will advance it, what haste comes here now? ye a letter: some dreg of my adversary's malice: come hither, what's the news!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A thing that concerns my mistress sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why then it concerns me knave?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I and you knave too, (Cry your worship mercy) you are both like to come into trouble I promise you sir, a precontract

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How a precontract sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I fear they have too much proof on't sir, old lucre he runs mad up and down and will to law as fast as he can, young Wit-good laid hold on by his creditors, he exclaims upon you a tother side, says you have wrought his undoing, by the injurious detaining of his contract.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Body a me?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He will have utmost satisfaction.
The law shall give him recompense he says.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Alas his creditors so merciless, my state being yet uncertain, I deem it not unconscionable to further him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: True sir —

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife, what says that letter let me construe it.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Cursed be my rash and unadvised words,
I'll set my foot upon my tongue,
And tread my inconsiderate grant to dust.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A pretty shift i'faith, I commend a woman when she can make away a letter from her husband handsomely, and this was cleanly done by my troth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I did sir?
Some foolish words I must confess did pass,
Which, now litigiously he fastens on me.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Of what force? let me examine 'em.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Too strong I fear, would I were well freed of him.

sp.speaker: Hoo,
sp.p: Shall I compound?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: No sir, I'd have it done some nobler way
Of your side; I'd have you come off with honour,
Let baseness keep with them: why have you not the means sir, the occasions offered you.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Where? how? dear wife.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: He is now caught by his creditors, the slave's needy, his debts petty, he'll rather bind himself, to all inconveniences then rot in prison, by this only means you may get a release from him, 'tis not yet come to his uncle's hearing, send speedily for the creditors, by this time he's desperate, he'll set his hand to any thing, take order for his debts, or discharge 'em quite, a pax on him, let's be rid of a rascal.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p:
Excellent, thou dost astonish me, go, run, make haste,
bring both the creditors and Wit-good hither.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: This will be some revenge yet.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: In the mean space I'll have a release drawne-within there.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Sirrah, come take derictions, go to my scrivener.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I'm yet like those, whose riches lie in dreams,
If I be waked they're false, such is my fate,
Who ventures deeper than the desperate state.
Though I have find yet could I become new,
For where I once vow, I am ever true.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Away, dispatch, on my displeasure, quickly, happy occasion, pray heaven he be in the right vain now to set his hand to't, that nothing alter him; grant that all his folly's may meet in him at once, to besot him enough.
I pray for him i'faith, and here he comes;

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What would you with me now, my uncle's spiteful adversary.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Nay I am friends,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I when your mischiefs spent.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I heard you were arrested.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Well, what then? you will pay none of my debts I am sure.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.l: A wiseman cannot tell,
There may be those conditions 'greed upon,
May move me to do much,

sp.speaker: Vvitt.
sp.l: I when 'tis thou perjured woman, oh no name
Is vild enough to match thy treachery,
That art the cause of my confusion.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Out you penurious slave.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Nay wife you are too froward,
Let him alone, give losers' leave to talk.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Shall I remember thee of another promise far stronger than the first.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I'd fain know that.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: 'Twould call shame to thy cheeks.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Shame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Hark in your ear. — will he come of thinkst thou, and pay my debts roundly.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Doubt nothing, there's a release a drawing and all to which you must set your hand.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
But methinks i'faith you might have made some
shift to discharge this yourself, having in the mortgage, and never have burdened my conscience with it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A my troth I could not, for my creditor's cruelties extend to the present.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: No more, — why do your worst for that, I defy you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You're impudent, I'll call up witnesses.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Call up thy wits for thou hast been devoted to follies a long time.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Wife, you're too bitter? Master Wit-good, and you my masters, you shall hear a mild speech come from me now, and this it is, 'thas been my fortune, gentlemen, to have an extraordinary blessing poured upon me o'late, and here she stands, I have wedded her and bedded her, and yet she is little the worse, some foolish words she hath passed to you in the country, and some peevish debts you owe here in the city, set the hare's head to the goose — giblet, release you her of her words, and I'll release you of your debts sir:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Would you so, I thank you for that sir, I cannot blame you i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why are not debts better than words sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Are not words promises, and are not promises debts sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: He plays at back-racket with me.
Come hither master Wit-good come hither, be ruled by fools once:
We are citizens and know what belong to't.
Take hold of his offer pax on her, let her go, if your debts were once discharged, I would help you to a widow myself worth ten of her.
Mass partner and now you remember me on't, there's master Muligrub's sister newly fallen a widow.

Cuds me, as pat as can be, there's a widow left for you, ten thousand in money, beside plate, jewels et caetera I warrant it a match, we can do all in all with her, prithee dispatch we'll carry thee to her presently.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My uncle will ne'er endure me, when he shall hear I set my hand to a release:

Hark, I'll tell thee a trick for that, I have spent five hundred pound in suits in my time, I should be wise, thou it now a
prisoner, make a release, take't of my word, whatsoever a man makes as long as he is in durance, 'tis nothing in law, not thus much.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Say you so sir?
I have paid for't I know't.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Proceed then, I consent.
Why well said:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How now my masters, what have you done with him?
With much ado sir, we have got him to consent.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ah — a — a, — and what came his debts to now?
Some eight score odd pounds sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Nau, nau, nau, nau, naw, tell me the second time, give me a lighter sum, they are but desperate debts you know, ne'er called in but upon such an accident, a poor needy knave he would starve and rot in prison, come, come, you shall have ten shillings in the pound and the sum down roundly —
You must make it a mark sir, —

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Go too then, tell your money in the mean time, you shall find little less there, — come master Wit-good you are so unwilling to do yourself good now, welcome honest scrivener, now you shall hear the release read, —

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: Be it known, to all men by these presents, that I Theodorus Wit-good, gentleman, sole nephew to pecunious lucre, having unjustly made title and claim, to one Jane Medler, late widow of Anthony Medler, and now wife to Walkadine Hoord, in consideration of a competent some of money to discharge my debts, do for ever hereafter disclaim any title, right, estate, or interest in or to the said widow late in the occupation of the said Anthony Medler, and now in the occupation of Walkadine Hoord, as also neither to lay claim, by virtue of any former contract, grant, promise or demise, to any of her manor, manor-house, parks, groves, meadow-grounds, arable lands, barns, stacks, stables, dove-holes, and coney-burrows, together with all her cattle, money, plate, jewels, borders, chains, bracelets, furnitures, hangings, movables, or immoueables in witness whereof I the said Theodorus Wit-good, have interchangeably set to my hand and seal before these presents, the day, and date above written.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: What a precious fortune hast thou slipped here like a beast as thou art?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Come, unwilling heart come.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Well master Hoord, give me the pen, I see
'Tis vain to quarrel with our destiny.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: O as vain a thing as can be, you cannot commit a greater absurdity sir, — so, so, give me that hand now, before all these presents I am friends for ever with thee.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth, and it were pity of my heart now, if I should bear you any grudge i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Content, I'll send for thy uncle against the wedding dinner, we will be friends once again.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I hope to bring it to pass myself sir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How now? is't right my masters?
'Tis something wanting sir, yet it shall be sufficient.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why well said, a good conscience makes a fine show now a day's, come my masters you shall all — taste of my wine ere you depart.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We follow you sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I'll try these fellows now, — a word sir, what will you carry me to that widow now?

Why do you think we were in earnest i'faith? carry you to a rich widow, we should get much credit by that; a noted rioter a contemptible prodigal, 'twas a trick we have amongst us, to get in our money, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Farewell and be hanged, you short-pig-haired ram-headed rascals, he that believes in you, shall ne'er be saved I warrant him, by this new league, I shall have some access unto my love —

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: Master Wit-good?

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: My life.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: Meet me presently, that note directs you, I would not be suspected our happiness attends us, farewell?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A words enough.

div.stage: Dampit the usurer in his bed, Audry spinning by.

lg.l: Let the usurer cram him, in interest that excel,
There's pits enough to dam him, before he comes to hell.
In Holborn, some: in fleet-street some,
Where ere he come, there's some there's some.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Trahe, traheto, draw the curtain, give me a sip of sack more.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Look you, did not I tell you he lay like the devil in chains, when he was bound for a thousand year.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: But I think the devil had no steel bedstaves, he goes beyond him for that.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Nay do but mark the conceit of his drinking, one must wipe his mouth for him with a muckender, do you see sir.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: Is this the sick trampler, why he is only bedrid with drinking.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: True sir, he spies us.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: What? sir Tristram? you come and see a weak man here, a very weak man, —

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: If you be weak in body, you should be strong in prayer sir.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: O, I have prayed too much poor man.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: There's a taste of his soul for you.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: Fah, loathsome?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: I come to borrow a hundred pound of you sir.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.l: Alas you come at an ill time, I cannot spare it i'faith,
I ha' but two thousand ith' house.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Out you gernative quean, the mullipood of villainy, the spinner of concupiscency.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Ye gentlemen are you here before us? how is he now?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Faith the same man still, the tavern bitch has bit him ith' head.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: We shall have the better sport with him, peace, and how cheers master Dampit now?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: O, my bosom sir Lancelot, how cheer I? thy presence is restorative:

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: But I hear a great complaint of you master Dampit, among gallants.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: I am glad of that i'faith; — prithee what?

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: They say you are waxed proud o'late, and if a friend visit you in the afternoon, you'll scarce know him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie, fie, proud? I cannot remember any such thing, sure I was drunk then.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: Think you so sir?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: There 'twas i'faith, nothing but the pride of the sack and so certify 'em, fetch sack sirrah.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A vengeance sack you once.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Why master Dampit if you hold on as you begin, and lie a little longer, you need not take care how to dispose your wealth, you'll make the vintner your heir.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Out you babliaminy, you unfettered cremitoried quean, you cullisance of scabiosity.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Good words master Dampit, to speak before a maid and a virgin.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Hang thy virginity, upon the pole of carnality.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Sweet terms, my mistress shall know 'em.

sp.speaker: Lam:
sp.p: Note but the misery of this usuring slave, here he lies like a noisome dunghill, full of the poison of his drunken blasphemies, and they to whom he bequeathes all, grudge him the very meat that feeds him, the very pillow that eases him, here may a usurer behold his end, what profits it to be a slave in this world, and a devil ith' next.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Sir Lancelot? let me buss thee sir Lancelot, thou art the only friend that I honour and respect.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I thank you for that master Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Farewell my bosom sir Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Gentlemen, and you love me, let me step behind you, and one of you fall a talking of me to him.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Content — master Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Here came sir Lancelot to see you e'en now.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hang him rascal.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Who sir Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pythagorical rascal.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Pythagorical?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I he changes his cloak when he meets a sergeant.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: What a rogue's this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I wonder you can rail at him sir, he comes in love to see you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A louse for his love, his father was a combmaker, I have no need of his crawling love, he comes to have longer day, the superlative rascal:

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: Sfoot I can no longer endure the rogue, master Dampit, I come to take my leave once again sir?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Who? my dear and kind sir Lancelot? the only gentleman of England, let me hug thee, farewell and a thousand.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Composed of wrongs and slavish flatteries.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Nay gentlemen, he shall show you more tricks yet, I'll give you another taste of him:

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: His memory is upon departing.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Another cup of sack.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Mass then 'twill be quite gone: before he drink that, tell him there's a country client come up, and here attends for his learned advice,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: One cup more, and then let the bell toll, I hope I shall be weak enough by that time.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Master Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Is the sack spouting.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: 'Tis coming forward sir, — here's a countryman a client of yours, waits for your deep and profound advice sir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A coxcombry? where is he? let him approach, set me up a peg higher.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: You must draw near sir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Now goodman foolaminy, what say you to me now

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Please your good worship, I am a poor man sir. —

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What make you in my chamber then?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I would entreat your worship's device in a just and honest cause sir. —

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I meddle with no such matters, I refer 'em, to master No-mans office.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I had but one house left me in all the world sir which was my fathers, my grandfathers, my great grandfathers, and now a villain has unjustly wrung me out, and took possession out.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Has he such feats? thy best course is to bring thy ejection firm, and in seven year thou mayst shove him out by the law.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Alas, an't please your worship, I have small friends and less money.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hoyda, this gear will fadge well, hast no money, why then my advice is thou must set fire ath' house and so get him out.

sp.speaker: Lam
sp.p: That will break strife indeed,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I thank your worship for your hot counsel sir. — altering but my voice a little, you see he knew me not, you may observe by this that a drunkard's memory, holds longer in the voice then in the person, but gentlemen shall I show you a sight, behold the little dive-dapper of damnation, gulf the usurer, for his time worse than tother.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: What's he comes with him?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Why Hoord, that married lately the widow meddler.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: O, I cry you mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Now gentlemen visitants? how dos master Dampit?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Faith here he lies e'en drawing — in sir, good canary as fast as he can sir, a very weak creature truly, he is almost past memory.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Fie master Dampit: you lie lazing a-bed here, and I come to invite you to my wedding dinner, up, up, up.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Who's this master Hoord! who hast thou married in the name of foolery.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A rich widow.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A Dutch widow.

sp.speaker: Hoo,
sp.p: A rich widow, — one widow meddler.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Medler she keeps open house.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: She did I can tell you in her tother husband's days, open house for all comers, horse and man was welcome, and room enough for 'em all.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: There's to much for thee then, thou mayst let out some to thy neighbours.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: What? hung alive in chains oh spectacle, bed staffs of steel, oh monstrum, horrendum, inform, ingens cvi lumen ademptum, oh Dampit, Dampit, here's a just judgement, shown upon usury, extortion, and trampling villainy.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: This exc'llent, thief rails upon the thief.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Is this the end of cut throat usury, brothel, and blasphemy? now mayst thou see what race a usurer runs.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why thou rogue of universality, do not I know thee? thy sound is like the cuckoo, the Welsh ambassador, thou cowardly slave that offers to fight with a sick man when his weapons down: rail upon me in my naked bed? why thou great Lucifer's little vicar, I am not so weak but I know a knave at first sight, thou inconscionable rascal, thou that goest upon Middlesex juries, and will make haste to give up thy verdict, because thou wilt not lose thy dinner, are you answered?

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: An't 'twere not for shame. —

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Thou wouldst be hanged then.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay you must exercise patience master gulf, always in a sick-man's chamber.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: he'll quarrel with none I warrant you, but those that are bedrid.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Let him come gentlemen, I am armed, reach my close stool hither.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Here will be a sweet fray anon, I'll leave you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay we'll a long with you, master gulf.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Hang him usuring rascal.

sp.speaker: Lan,
sp.p: Push, set your strength to his, your wit to his.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Pray gentlemen depart, his hours come upon him, sleep in my bosom, sleep.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.l: Nay we have enough of him i'faith, keep him for the house. — now ▪ make your best.
For thrice his wealth, I would not have his breast.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: A little thing would make me beat him, now he's asleep.

sp.speaker: Lan
sp.l: Mass then 'twill be a pitiful day when he wakes.
I would be loath to see that day, come.

sp.speaker: Lul:
sp.p: You overrule me gentlemen i'faith.

div.head: Actus. 5.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay uncle, let me prevail with you so much,
I'faith go, now he has invited you,

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: I shall have great joy there, when he has born away the widow.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why la, I thought where I should find you presently;
Uncle, a my troth, 'tis nothing so.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's nothing so sir, is not he married to the widow.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: No by my troth is he not uncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will you have the truth out, he is married to a whore i'faith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I should laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Uncle, let me perish in your favour if you find it not so and that 'tis I that have married the honest woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha? I'd walk ten mile a foot to see that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And see'te you shall, or I'll ne'er see you again.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A quean i'faith? ha, ha, ha.

div.stage: Enter Hoord tasting wine the host following in a livery cloak.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Pup, pup, pup, pup, I like not this wine, is there never a better teirs in the house.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yes sir, there are as good teirs in the house, as any are in England.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Desire your mistress you knave, to taste 'em all over, she has better skill.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Has she so, the better for her . and the worse for you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Arthur, is the cupboard of plate set out,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: All's in order sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I am in love with my liveries every time I think on 'em, they make a gallant show by my troth. — niece.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: Do you call sir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Prithee show a little diligence, and overlook the knaves a little, they'll filch and steal today and send whole pasties home to their wives, and thou beest a good niece, do not see me purloined.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: Fear it not sir, I have cause, though the feast be prepared for you, yet it serves fit for my wedding dinner too.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Master Lamprey, and master Spichcocke two the most welcome gentlemen alive, your fathers and mine were all free ath' fishmongers.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: They were indeed sir, you see bold guests sir, soon entreated

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And that's best sir — how now sirrah?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: There's a coach come to'th door sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: My lady Foxstone a my life. Mistress Jane Hoord, wife, mass 'tis her ladyship indeed, madam you are welcome to an unfurnished house, dearth of cheer, scarcity of attendance.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You are pleased to make the worst sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is this your bride.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Yes madam salute my lady Foxtone.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Please you madam a while to taste the air in the garden?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Twill please us well.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Who would not wed the most delicious life,
No joys are like the comforts of a wife.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: So we bachelors think that are not troubled with them

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Your worship's brother with another ancient gentleman, are newly alighted sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Master Onesiphorus Hoord, why now our company begins to come in: my dear and kind brother welcome i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ony:
sp.p: You see we are men at an hour brother.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ay, I'll say that for you brother you keep as good an hour to come to a feast, as any gentleman in the sheer . what old master limber and master kicks, do we meet i'faith jolly gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: We hope you lack guess sir?

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: O welcome, welcome, we lack still such guess as your worships.

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Ah sirrah brother, have you catched up widow Medler.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: From 'em all brother, and I may tell you, I had mighty enemies, those that stuck sore, old lucre is a sore fox I can tell you brother.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Where is she, I'll go seek her out, I long to have a smack at her lips.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And most wishfully brother see where she comes, give her a smirk now we may hear it all the house over.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O heaven, I am betrayed, I know that face.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, why how now? are you both a shamed? come gentlemen, we'll look another way —

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Nay brother, hark you, come you're disposed to be merry?

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Why do we meet else man?

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: That's another matter, I was ne'er so 'fraid in my life but that you had been in earnest.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How mean you brother?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: You said she was your wife?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Did I so? by my troth and so she is.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: By your troth brother?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What reason have I to dissemble with my friends, brother, if marriage can make her mine, she is mine? why?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Troth I am not well of a sudden? I must crave pardon brother, I came to see you, but I cannot stay dinner i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I hope you will not serve me so brother.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: By your leave master Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What now? what now? pray gentlemen, you were wont to show yourselves wise-men.

sp.speaker: Lim,
sp.p: But you have shown your folly too much here.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Kix.
sp.l: Fie, fie, a man of your repute and name,
You'll feast your friends but cloy 'em first with shame.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: This grows too deep pray let us reach the sense.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: In your old age dote on a courtesan —

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Kixe.
sp.p: Marry a strumpet?

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Ony:
sp.p: And Wit-good's quean:

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: O, nor lands, nor living?

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Living?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Speak?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Alas you know at first sir,
I told you I had nothing:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Out, out, I am cheated, infinitely cozened.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay master Hoord:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A Dutch widow, a Dutch widow, a Dutch widow:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why nephew shall I trace thee still a liar? wilt make me mad is not yond thing the widow.

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: Why la, you are so hard a belief uncle, by my troth she's a whore.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: Then thou'rt a knave:

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: Negatur argumentum uncle.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Probo tibi, nephew: he that knows a woman to be a quean must needs be a knave, thou sayst thou knowest her to be one, ergo if she be a quean thou'rt a knave:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Negatur, sequela maioris, uncle, he that knows a woman to be a quean, must needs be a knave, I deny that.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Lucre, and Wit-good, you're both villains, get you out of my house:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Why didst not invite me to thy wedding dinner?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And are not you and I sworn perpetual friends before witness sir, and were both drunk upon't.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Daintily abused you've put a junt upon me:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A common strumpet?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Nay now you wrong her sir , if I were she I'd have the law on you for that, I durst depose for her, she ne'er had common use, nor common thought.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Despise me, publish me I am your wife,
What shame can I have now but you'll have part,
If in disgrace you share, I sought not you:
You pursued me, nay forced me,
Had I friends would follow it,
Less than your action has been proved a rape.

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Brother?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Nor did I ever boast of lands unto you,
Money or goods: I took a plainer course:
And told you true I'd nothing,
If error were committed 'twas by you.

thank your own folly, nor has my sin been so odious but worse has been for given, nor am I so deformed but I may challenge the utmost power of any old man's love, she that tastes not sin before, twenty to one but she'll taste it after: most of you old men are content to marry young virgins and take that which follows, where marrying one of us, you both save a sinner, and are quit from a cuckold for ever,
"And more in brief let this your best thoughts win,
" she that knows sin, knows best how to hate sin.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Cursed be all malice, black are the fruits of spite,
And poison first their owners: oh my friends,
I must embrace shame, to be rid of shame,
Concealed disgrace prevents a public name.
Ah Wit-good ah Theodorus,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alas sir, I was prick tin conscience to see her well bestowed ▪ and where could I bestow her beter than upon your pitiful worship: excepting but myself, I dare swear she's a virgin, and now by marrying your niece I have banished myself for ever from her, she's mine aunt now by my faith, and there's no meddling with mine aunt you know, a sin against my nuncle.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Lo, gentlemen, before you all.
In true reclaimed form I fall,
Henceforth for ever I defy,
The glances of a sinful eye,
Waving of fans, which some suppose,
Tricks of fancy, treading of toes,
Wringing of fingers, biting the lip,
The wanton gate th' alluring trip,
All secret friends and private meetings,
Close born letters, and bawds greetings,
Feigning excuse to women's labours,
When we are sent for to'th next neighbours,
Taking false physic, and ne'er start,
To be let blood, though sign be at heart,
Removing chambers, shifting beds,
To welcome friends in husband's steads,
Them to enjoy, and you to marry,
they first served, while you must tarry,
They to spend and you to gather,
They to get and you to father,
These and thousand thousand more,
New reclaimed I now abhor.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A, here's a lesson rioter for you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I must confess my follies, I'll down to
And here for ever I disclaim,
The cause of youths undoing. Game:
Chiefly dice, those true outlanders,
That shake out beggars, thieves and panders,
Soul wasting surfeits, sinful riots,
Queans evils, doctors diets.
Pothecary's drugs, surgeons glisters,
Stabbing of arms for a common mistress,
Ribbon favours . ribald speeches,
Dear perfumed jackets, pennyless breeches,
Dutch flapdragons, healths in urine,
Drabs that keep a man too sure in:
I do defy you all.
Lend me each honest hand, for here I rise,
A reclaimed man loathing the general vice.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.l: So, so, all friends, the wedding dinner cools,
Who seem most crafty prove oft times most fools.
